title: How to Make Johnnycake

steps.headline: Combine the cornmeal and salt.
steps.description: Get out a medium mixing bowl and measure 1 cup (120 g) of white cornmeal and 3/4 teaspoon of salt into it. Use a whisk or a fork to stir the cornmeal and salt together.

steps.headline: Pour hot water into the bowl of cornmeal.
steps.description: Bring 1 cup (236 ml) of water to boil. Slowly pour the water into the bowl of cornmeal while you stir it. Keep stirring the mushy cornmeal. You can heat the water in a pan on the stove or use a water kettle.

steps.headline: Stir in the milk and heat the pan.
steps.description: Slowly pour 1/2 cup (120 ml) of milk into the cornmeal mixture and stir it well. Set the batter aside while you heat a heavy skillet over medium heat. Grease the skillet with bacon drippings or shortening. The batter should be pretty thick, since there isn't very much liquid in it. You don't need to heat the milk before you add it.

steps.headline: Fry several spoonfuls of johnnycake batter.
steps.description: Once the skillet is hot, scoop a spoonful of batter and drop it into the pan. Press down on each johnnycake, so they flatten to 1/4-inch (6 mm) thick. Flip them over with a spatula once they're golden brown on each side. You can probably fry half a dozen johnnycakes at a time. If they begin to stick to the skillet, spread more bacon drippings on the pan.

steps.headline: Finish frying the johnnycakes and serve them.
steps.description:
Fry the rest of the New England johnnycakes in batches. Set them on a serving plate and serve them with:
Butter
Maple syrup
Applesauce

steps.headline: Preheat the oven and prepare the pan.
steps.description: Turn the oven on to 325 degrees F (160 C). Get out a 9 x 9-inch (23 x 23-cm) pan and coat it with cooking spray or grease. Set the pan aside while you make the johnnycake batter.

steps.headline: Cream the butter and sugar.
steps.description: Place ½ cup (113 g) of softened butter and ¾ cups (150 g) of sugar into a mixing bowl. Use a stand or electric mixer to beat the butter and sugar together on medium-low speed. The mixture should lighten a little in color.

steps.headline: Stir in the remaining ingredients.
steps.description: Add 4 cups (400 g) of flour, ½ cup (120 ml) of water, ½ teaspoon of salt, and 2 teaspoons baking powder to the bowl. Stir the batter on low speed while you slowly pour in ¾ cup (180 ml) of milk. The batter should look thick and sticky at this point.

steps.headline: Spread and flatten the dough in the pan.
steps.description: Scoop the batter into the prepared baking pan. Spread it evenly with a spatula. Or, dust your hands with flour and press down gently on the batter in the pan, so it becomes level.

steps.headline: Bake the Bahamian johnnycake.
steps.description: Put the pan in the oven and bake the johnnycake for one hour. The edges of the johnnycake should turn golden brown while the center will still remain light. Cool the johnnycake for a few minutes before you cut and serve it. The johnnycake will not rise as much as a cake or traditional cornbread.

steps.headline: Whisk the dry ingredients.
steps.description:
Place all of the dry ingredients into a large mixing bowl. Whisk them together for about 30 seconds. You'll need:
2 cups (150 g) unbleached flour
4 teaspoons baking powder
1/2 teaspoon fine sea salt
2 tablespoons sugar

steps.headline: Rub in the butter and add the liquid ingredients.
steps.description: Use your fingers to rub in 1/2 tablespoon of cold butter until the mixture looks like breadcrumbs. Pour in 1/2 cup (120 ml) of whole milk and 1/4 cup (60 ml) of water. Use your hands to stir the mixture into a shaggy dough.

steps.headline: Knead the dough.
steps.description: Sprinkle a little flour on a work surface and dump the dough onto it. Use your hands to knead the dough for about five minutes. The dough will be really sticky when you start, but it should become soft and elastic once you've finished kneading. Avoid adding too much flour or the johnnycake will become tough.

steps.headline: Rest the dough.
steps.description: Put the dough into a bowl and cover the bowl with plastic wrap. This will keep a tough skin from forming on the dough. Let the dough rest in the bowl for one hour.

steps.headline: Portion the dough into balls.
steps.description: Get a sheet pan out and dust it with flour. Remove the plastic wrap from the bowl of dough and scoop out enough dough to make a ball. The ball should be 2 to 3-inches (5 to 7.5-cm) in size. Roll it between the palms of your hand to round out the shape and set it on your prepared baking pan. Continue to portion out the rest of the dough into balls. You won't be baking the johnnycake on the sheet. The floured sheet is just where you'll keep the balls of dough until you're ready to shape and fry them.

steps.headline: Heat the oil for frying.
steps.description: Get a deep frying pan or skillet out and place it on your stove. Pour canola or vegetable oil into the pan, so the oil comes about 1 to 2-inches (2.5 to 5-cm) up the side of the pan. Turn the heat up to medium. You'll know the oil is hot enough to fry the johnnycakes by carefully dripping a drop of water into it. When the oil is hot, the water will pop as it hits it.

steps.headline: Stretch the dough balls.
steps.description: Take a ball of johnnycake dough and gently stretch it into a circle. It should be about 1/4 to 1/2-inch (6 to 12 mm) thick. You should use your hands to stretch the dough, but avoid simply pressing down to flatten the dough. Stretch the remaining balls of dough. Stretching the dough will develop the gluten in the johnnycake, which will make it light and puffy.

steps.headline: Place a few johnnycakes in the hot oil.
steps.description: Place two or three of the johnnycakes into the hot oil and fry them until they're golden on the bottom. Check them after a minute and then flip them over, so they become golden brown on the other side. Use a slotted spoon to scoop out the fried johnny cakes and set them on a paper towel. You'll need to fry the rest of the johnnycakes in batches, but remember to let the oil heat back up in between batches.
